title: Will there ever be a new coin in the U.S.? - Quora
tags: Money in the United States of America
Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: QUESTION “Will there ever be a new coin in the U.S.?” ANSWER The US Mint produces a number of interesting products, but as of 2020, there are four coins that you’re liable to see on a daily basis:  If you’re wondering whether you’ll see a new design, we think you will. The cent was given a reverse makeover in 2010, the nickel was given a new obverse in 2006, and the quarter reverse has been lent out to three different series since 1999, so this is the 22nd year of those. But the overall design of the dime, obverse and reverse, is the same now as it was when introduced in 1946. So we think it’s about due. Ronald Reagan would be a great candidate for the dime. Likewise, inflation eventually makes fools of all currency. All of our gold coins are gone now, the silver came out of the coins in the 1960s, the copper came out of the cent in 1982, and the nickel in the nickel is still the same now as it was in 1866. So —- that will probably go next. We’ve watched as all of Europe went from noble metal to junk metal for their coins and we think that America is probably doomed to that route, since we have allowed our dollar to inflate by almost 30 times in two hundred years. The mission of the US Mint is to produce readily identifiable, practical, durable coins that the public can trust, and use to express their wealth. As it stands, the coin that the Mint produces the most of, by far, is the cent. Trucks and trains haul billions of these things every year — problem is, you can’t buy anything with a cent. Vending machines won’t even take ’em. The self-serve checkout at Walmart will, or the Coinstar, but usually it’s roll-’em-up and turn-’em-in, and that’s no good. America should accept a dollar coin, but, so far, they don’t. Maybe it’s because the Treasury keeps pumping out the dollar bill, but no matter what the Mint does, those dollar coins end up not circulating. The Mint gave up making them for circulation in 2012, and gave up the half dollar in 2003. (Our dollar coin is really popular in Ecuador and other dollarized foreign countries, we’re told. But we digress.) So there’s not one coin the Mint makes, that people use, that has the buying power of the first coin they made, the 1793 Large Cent. We’re literally down to paper money and cards when we buy something more costly than a Snickers bar or a Coke, each of which now regularly retails for more than two dollars. We shouldn’t have to plunk more than five coins into a machine to get a snack. If we can keep the lineup of coins we currently have for one more generation, maybe it won’t matter. Maybe even the older folks will figure out PaySquare or ThumbIt or whatever comes next. But what will the kids do? Will six year-olds have bank accounts or PayPal and pay with their phones? Hopefully, the coin lineup will go to “quarter, half dollar, dollar, five dollars,” although it might go to “half dollar, dollar, five dollars, ten dollars.” But the darned small change is not accomplishing much other than damaging our pants pockets for not enough good reason. Just sayin’.

“Ever” is a very long time. Oceans rise and empires fall, but I suspect the United States will remain a viable state long enough to issue different coins.There are new coins every year, but most of the are for collectors. Subtle changes are made to existing coins as well.If you are asking about different denominations such as 2 cents, 3 cents, or 20 cents, the United States tried all three in the 19th century. There’s just no perceived need. Nor has the U.S. public embraced the idea of a $1 coin, despite the fact that many other countries have coins of similar or higher value.
